questions.text: What does a Serial actress wanted to get wrinkles removed from her face and was given a local injection of Botulinum toxin. Does that acts through?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Inhibition of acetylcholine release

Highyeild:

Botulinum toxin acts by presynaptic inhibition of acetylcholine release. When injected locally it causes muscle relaxation and is hence used in cosmetics for treating wrinkles and glabellar lines Other uses of Botulinum toxin: Glabellar lines (moderate to severe) Blepharospasm associated with dystonia Cervical dystonia Migraine prophylaxis Overactive bladder Strabismus Severe upper limb spasticity Severe axillary hyperhidrosis The action of botulinum toxin at the synaptic cleft. Botulinum toxin acts on synaptobrevin and blocks the release of neurotransmitters from the cleft.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B . Direct action on acetylcholine esterase: Some drugs act through direct action on acetylcholine esterase. They inhibit this enzyme & increase the action of Acetylcholine on receptors. Eg: Physostigmine, Neostigmine, Pyridostigmine, Donepezil, Galantamine, Tacrine, etc. Option: C . Direct action on muscarinic receptors: These drugs act through direct action on muscarinic receptors. Eg: Acetylcholine, Methacholine, Bethanechol, Carbachol, etc. Option: D . Inhibition of choline uptake: Hemicholinium (HC3) blocks choline uptake (the rate-limiting step in ACh synthesis) and depletes ACh.

questions.text: A 48-year-old female patient complains of dry mouth and dryness of the eyes. Her investigation showed the presence of anti-SS-A & anti-SS-B antibodies. Which of the following drugs would help in managing this patient’s dryness of mouth?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cevimeline A 48-year-old female patient with complaints of dry mouth and dryness of eyes and investigation showing the presence of anti-SS-A or anti-SS-B antibodies point towards a diagnosis of Sjogren’s syndrome. Cevimeline is a muscarinic agonist that preferentially activates M1 and M3 receptors on lacrimal and salivary gland epithelia. The drug has a long-lasting sialogogic action and may have fewer side effects and better patient compliance than pilocarpine. Hence, this drug would help in managing this patient’s symptoms

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Carbachol, Option B. Methacholine, and Option D. Bethanechol are cholinergic, but not approved for xerostomia (dryness of the mouth).

Extraedge:

The drug has a long-lasting sialogogic action and may have fewer side effects and better patient compliance than pilocarpine. Hence, this drug would help in managing this patient’s symptoms

questions.text: Mr. Zee, aged 38 years, comes to the OPD with complaints of drooping of eyelids, difficulty while chewing food, and weakness of upper and lower limbs, which fluctuates in intensity over time. The physician wants to confirm myasthenia gravis. The drug used to diagnose this condition is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Edrophonium It is a short-acting Anticholinesterase It is used in the diagnosis of myasthenia gravis Differentiate between cholinergic & myasthenia crises.

Highyeild:

Edrophonium test It is done by rapid intravenous injection of 2 mg of edrophonium and checking for a response, If there is no response, then give 8mg after 45 sec later. If there is a brief improvement in strength, the test is positive (myasthenia crisis). If there is weakness, then it is called a cholinergic crisis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Rivastigmine is a reversible anticholinesterase & it is used in the treatment of. Alzheimer's Disease. Option: C. Physostigmine is a reversible anticholinesterase & it is used in the treatment of glaucoma & it is the drug of choice for atropine poisoning. Option: D . Malathion is an irreversible anticholinesterase belonging to the organophosphate group. It is used as an insecticide & also used in the treatment of head lice.

Table:

Edrophonium (Tensilon) Test: Edrophonium chloride inhibits acetylcholinesterase, thereby prolonging the presence of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction. This results in enhanced muscle strength. In ptosis, a positive test is the elevation of eyelids in 2-5 minutes post adminstration of Tensilon. A negative response is no improvement within 3 minutes. the Tensilon test has a relatively low sensitivity, approximately 60% for MG. False positive results occur in patients with Lambert-Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome (LEMS), Amyothrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS), and localized intracranial mass lesions. Edrophonium chloride can cause overactivation of the parasympathetic system, and cause unwanted side effects like fainting, dizziness, involuntary defecation, severe bradycardia, apnea, and even cardiac arrest. It is important to always have atropine at hand if such side effects should occur

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presented to OPD with muscle weakness and ptosis. The Tensilon test was positive and other neurological investigations were normal. He was given pyridostigmine for the treatment and after a few days, the patient had increased salivation and diarrhea. Which drug is used to control the symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Glycopyrrolate

Highyeild:

The diagnosis from history is myasthenia gravis Hence, the patient was started with an oral anticholinesterase (pyridostigmine). Then the patient had to face muscarinic side effects like salivation & diarrhea. These muscarinic side effects can be controlled with the use of oral anticholinergic drugs that have little or no effect on the nicotinic receptors. Among the given options, Glycopyrrolate is an anticholinergic, used to control muscarinic side effects.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Physostigmine is a cholinergic drug. Option: C . Prazosin is an alpha-blocker. Option :D. Metoprolol is a beta-blocker. Hence, they are not used for the treatment of muscarinic side effects.

Extraedge:

Glycopyrrolate Clinical Considerations cannot cross the BBB Devoid of CNS & Opthalmic activity Potent inhibitor of salivary gl. & respiratory tract secretion HR increases after IV injection but not IM Longer duration of action than Atropine (2~4hr vs. 30 min)

questions.text: A 58-year-old patient had laryngeal cancer for that she went neck irradiation. After that, she developed a dry mouth and decreased salivary secretion. Which of the following drug is not useful in the above condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Glycopyrrolate Drugs used for dry mouth/ Sjogren’s are cholinergic drugs such as Cevimeline Anticholinesterase drugs Pilocarpine Glycopyrrolate (Option B) is an anticholinergic drug with M3 receptor blocking action at the glands, which itself leads to dryness of the mouth Glycopyrrolate is used: As a pre-anesthetic medication to decrease secretions (a quaternary compound that does not cross BBB) To reduce salivary, tracheobronchial, and pharyngeal secretions & gastric secretions; and To block cardiac vagal inhibitory reflexes during induction of anesthesia and intubation

questions.text: A villager who was working in the field came to the emergency room with a snake bite. With history, it was from cobra and was given Anti snake venom. The doctor gave neostigmine combined with atropine to:

options.label: D
options.text: Increase neostigmine entry to the brain

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Decrease muscarinic adverse effects

Highyeild:

Cobra venom contains a curare-like neurotoxin, which may cause respiratory paralysis and death. This neurotoxin causes NM blockade similar to d-tubocurarine poisoning To overcome this, we need to increase ACh levels at the neuromuscular junction and prevent respiratory paralysis Neostigmine is an anticholinesterase drug that increases ACh levels by inhibiting the cholinesterase enzyme. The increased ACh acts both on the M and N receptor. But we need action only at the N receptor of the neuromuscular junction. So, we block M receptor action by giving atropine and decreasing muscarinic adverse effects

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Increase the efficacy of neostigmine & Option B. Decrease efficacy of neostigmine: Atropine won’t increase/ decrease the efficacy of neostigmine. Option :D. Increase neostigmine entry to the brain: Neostigmine does not penetrate the brain even if it is combined with atropine. Hence, these are the wrong options.

Extraedge:

Classification of snakes Snakes can be classified into poisonous and non- poisonous. Poisonous snakes belong to three Families on the basis of poison secreted : Elapidae: Neurotoxic Viperidae : Haemotoxic Hydrophidae: Myotoxic

questions.text: A 55-year-old farmer was brought to casualty with symptoms of severe abdominal cramps with vomiting, diarrhea, profuse lacrimation, and salivation. His BP was 80/60 mm Hg. Pupillary constriction is marked. The drug used in the management of the above poisoning is which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Atropine Atropine is used to treat myopia and inflammation in the eyes (uveitis or iritis). It is also used for the eye examination and diagnose eye problems like blurred vision or squint in children

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Malathion is an OP compound Option: B. Physostigmine & Option C . Pilocarpine are cholinergic drugs that will increase cholinergic properties and worsen the condition

Extraedge:

It is a typical case of Organophosphate (OP) poisoning Severe abdominal cramps with vomiting, diarrhea, profuse lacrimation, and salivation point towards cholinergic excess due to the anticholinesterase activity of OP compounds The antidote for OP poisoning is atropine

questions.text: A 45-year-old female was brought to casualty with symptoms of vomiting, diarrhea, profuse lacrimation, salivation, and miosis. She had taken an OP compound to commit suicide. She was immediately started on atropine and the junior resident in the medicine department was told to watch for signs of atropinization. Which of the following is an indicator of adequate atropinisation?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pupillary dilation Indicators of adequate atropinization are an increase in heart rate (Not decrease – Option A), pupillary dilation (commonly used criteria), and absence of secretions

Highyeild:

Arged end-points for atropinization Disappearance of crepitations and wheezes on chest Auscultation Pulse>80 beats/min Systolic BP>80 mmHg Pupils no longer pinpoint Dry axillae

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A -Atropine causes an increase in heart rate and pulse and not a decrease. Option: C- Absence Not increase – of pulmonary secretions (most reliable criteria) Option :D. Increased urination will be in OP poisoning. It is not a sign of atropinisation.)

questions.text: A 23-year-old male Mr. X was brought to the emergency room by his father. When the father was asked about history, the father told that Mr. X ate some seeds from a plant and started behaving crazy. On examination he was confused, his skin was hot and dry. His pupils were dilated and unresponsive to light. Blood pressure was 180/105 mm Hg, pulse 150/min, and rectal temperature 40 C (104 F). The treatment of choice for the above poisoning is which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Physostigmine This is a case of atropine poisoning probably from datura seeds Confusion, hot and dry skin, tachycardia, pupils dilated, and high-temperature point toward datura poisoning Datura stramonium is a widespread annual plant, containing atropine, hyoscyamine, and scopolamine, which can produce poisoning with a severe anticholinergic syndrome. Teenagers ingest the roots, seeds, or the entire plant to obtain its hallucinogenic and euphoric effects Physostigmine 5–2 mg i.v is the specific antidote for atropine poisoning It crosses the blood-brain barrier and antagonizes both central and peripheral actions Neostigmine and pyridostigmine don’t cross BBB

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. These consist of a sugar (glycone) and a non-sugar moiety (aglycone). These drugs are collectively known as digitalis. Compounds in this group include digoxin, digitoxin, strophanthin and ouabain etc. Cardiac glycosides are positive inotropic drugs but unlike other inotropes, these do not increase heart rate or oxygen consumption (rather heart rate and oxygen consumption are decreased by digitalis). These drugs can be used as acute treatment of CHF as well as for maintenance (digoxin) but these do not alter the basic pathology and thus are unable to decrease the mortality. Cardiac glycosides are also used for the treatment of atrial fibrillation, atrial flutter, and paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (DOC is adenosine). Digitalis is the only inotropic drug available that can be given orally. Option: C D. Atropine is a non-selective antagonist at muscarinic receptors. It can penetrate the blood-brain barrier and reverse the muscarinic action in the CNS. It can also reverse hypertension and bronchoconstriction caused due to stimulation of muscarinic receptors. However, muscle paralysis is due to Nicotinic (N) action on which it has no activity.

Extraedge:

PHARMACOLOGY: PHYSOSTIGMINE & NEOSTIGMINE are carbamates Drugs → reversibly inhibit ACETYLCHOLINESTERASE→ increase ACh → stimulate muscarinic & nicotinic receptors Physostigmine has TERTIARY AMINE STRUCTURE → penetrates BBB → exerts cholinergic effects in the CNS Neostigmine → is a QUATERNARY AMMONIUM COMPOUND → doesn't cross BBB FOR PHYSOSTIGMINE: Onset of action: 3-8 min FOR NEOSTIGMINE: Onset of action: 7-11 mins Duration of action: 30-90 mins Duration of action: 1-2 hours.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male came with complaints of impaired gait or movement, language difficulties, low energy, memory loss, and mood swings. Investigations revealed positive amyloid on PET imaging and an increase in CSF total tau and phospho-tau. Which drug used in the management of the above condition is not a cholinergic drug?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Memantine This is a case of Alzheimer’s disease Option A. Rivastigmine, Option B. Donepezil & Option C. Galantamine are anticholinesterases that increase ACh levels in the brain. Hence. They are used for Alzheimer’s disease

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option :D. Memantine is not an anticholinesterase drug, it is a NMDA antagonist used in Alzheimer’s disease Rivastigmine is available as transdermal patch Tacrine, an anticholinesterase that was also used for Alzheimer's disease is not used nowadays due to hepatotoxicity.

questions.correct_answer: D. Paralysis of accommodation and mydriasis
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Paralysis of accommodation and mydriasis

Highyeild:

Anticholinergic mydriatic drugs cause paralysis of accommodation and passive mydriasis by relaxing sphincter pupillae Cholinergic drugs cause spasms of accommodation and miosis by contraction of sphincter pupillae eg. Pilocarpine Drugs include Homatropine, cyclopentolate, and tropicamide

Extraedge:

Mydriasis is mainly caused by the agents which are muscarinic (M3) antagonists (indirect) and adrenoreceptor (a1/a2) agonists (direct). Miosis is caused by the agents which are muscarinic (M3) agonists (direct) and adrenoreceptor (a1/a2) antagonists (indirect)
